segments.text: collected for Dr. Ball, were you paid for that on a piece basis?
No, about twenty-five cents an hour.
On an hourly basis?
On an hourly basis, and that was the rate of pay in those days.
What types of specimens did you collect?
Oh, I would go out and collect rhizomes.
I would collect
shrubs and buds and various things that were used for the laboratory part of his botany classes.
This was prior to the creation of the museum building, I think, here on campus, was it not?
Oh, yes, yes.
That's long before that.
So none of your specimens ended up in the museum, I take it?
No, I would think not.
They ended up in the laboratory part of his classes and probably in the garbage or the wastebasket after the class was over.
Okay.
What types of things did you do in the swine farm?
I fed swine, and I remember, among other things, many other things, I would move the swine from here to there, and all kinds of operations, repairing of fences, repairing of feeder troughs, etc.
I remember very distinctly that when the dairy at that time, the creamer really, was actually dumping a lot of skim milk into the sewer line, and it was causing Mr. Zeller, P.J.
Zeller, who was in charge of sewer disposal at that time,
it was causing him troubles at the sewer disposal plants out here so he devised a means of precipitating the casein out of that skim milk so it wouldn't get into his
sewage disposal area.
And so we wondered if it couldn't be used possibly as a feed for swine.
So I devised a little experiment, and we set up and carried that experiment through.
And it fed it at two different levels.
And it proved to be a very excellent feed, as a matter of fact.
And I suppose that's my first research experiment that I ever did.
This swine herd that you were working with, was that used in the Agricultural Experiment Station?
No, no.
In those days, as you know, until about 1947, I think, the teaching herds were all completely independent.
of the research.
And so the research swine herd was out at what we call the F&B.
It's out where the old part of the dairy center is, just out past where the water tank is out there.
And then the swine teaching farm was located right out here, as I say, right on the top of this hill.
The golf course.
The golf course, where the golf course is.
So these swine were used in the animal science teaching?
Teaching, strictly, yes.
Well, did the students do research with them, or in what aspect of teaching were they used?
No, they made it possible.
What they did, they took.
for income for the animal husbandry department, they collected the garbage from Spiesel Hall.
And they brought it out to the swine, among other things.
Now, they didn't do it all that way.
but they had a fairly large group of swine that they fed this garbage to.
Well, we were able to pick out of this group, pick out the animals and match them up that we could put on this little test for the whey, the precipitated whey from the skim milk.
That's how.
As far as I know, that was the only experiment that was conducted of that sort.
Then did the department sell parts of the herd as they reached proper weight?
Yes, always.
The income from the sale of the herd went right back into the department of budget, yes.
Then did Animal Husband Department have other...
I take it they had a...
a dairy herd and other livestock which they used for the same purpose?
No, there was a separate dairy department.
And there was, the dairy department had the dairy herd.
But there was, the animal husbandry department had the swine, had beef, and the beef barn was located right where the Herman Heath building is now, right back of the judging pavilion.
And let's see, they had sheep and goats.
And these were the animals, I guess, that the Animal Husbandry Department had.
Sheep and Goat Center was over where the dormitory area, these 12 dormitories are over here.
The Corps of Cadets dormitories.
Yeah, right, right.
Okay, did any of this livestock from Animal Husbandry
Was it ever served in a dining hall?
I mean, did you sell it to what would now be food services?
Do you remember?
I don't remember.
I doubt if it did, because there was no processing plant.
See, it would have had to have been processed.
I see.
And so it was probably sold to, I guess I shouldn't use these names, Armour, Swift, or Wilson or something.
Commercial.
Commercial processing, yeah.
So the meat lab then is a more recent process.
Yes, yes indeed.
You see, the meat lab was, I graduated from A&M in 1931, and this building where the meats lab is, including the meats lab, was built in 1933.
Let's see.
In 31, when you graduated then, you, I believe, went to the University of Illinois.
Right.
For a master's.
I had intended, since I'd had to borrow, and incidentally, the swine herdsman, a man by the name of Chrysler,
had loaned me, I couldn't make the 25 cents an hour, just couldn't make my way through college.
And so he had loaned me and I owed him a little bit of money when I graduated.
And I was going out and work for a year and pay that back before I went to graduate college.
I had definitely planned all of my coursework.
to go to graduate college.
This I knew.
I was going to graduate school.
But I did this.
But there absolutely, as far as I could find, there was absolutely no jobs.
available anywhere in 1931.
So I waited and waited.
I turned down.
I had an opportunity for an assistantship or two at other institutions during the latter part of my senior, the last semester of my senior year.
I turned them down because I thought I had to get a job and I wanted to pay this money back before I went to graduate college.
Well, it came June and July and still no job and so it just happened that an assistantship at the University of Illinois became available and the man that
had accepted it became ill and could not go on to school.
And so they notified the people here the availability of this assistantship.
And I was notified about it.
And so I immediately made application and was fortunate enough to get the assistantship.
In those days, there weren't many assistantships.
And so I was very fortunate.
And that's how I happened to go.
I had planned to go to the University of Illinois anyhow, but it happened that this assistantship was in genetics, and I had planned to go there to major in nutrition.
So you had to make a change of plans.
Yes, sir.
Why did you choose the University of Illinois?
Majorly because one of the professors that I liked and respected on the staff here was a graduate of Illinois and knew the people and told me a lot about some of the people.
And I had read about H.H.
Mitchell who was fairly well known in the field of protein nutrition.
at the University of Illinois.
So again, it was a matter of people making the choices as making the choice to come to A&M.
So you went there and you had an assistantship in genetics.
Did that require you to major in genetics?
Yes, animal genetics, but I took as many or more courses.
My major professor was quite liberal, and I took more courses, probably, in fact I know, more courses in nutrition than I did in genetics, so I really ended up with a joint
major between the fields of nutrition and genetics.
Now, at this point, were you specializing in poultry or did that come even later?
No, no.
disciplines were independent of animal commodity commitments.
And I took some courses under the Dr. Leslie Card, who was the head of the poultry section of the animal husbandry department at the University of Illinois.
It was all in one department there.
They weren't divided up.
And I took some coursework in poultry with the idea that my commitment in nutrition or in genetics would require a commodity field.
And so taking the courses in poultry, it prepared me then to go into the poultry area when I went into a commodity grouping.
After you finished your master's, you went directly into a PhD program?
Yes.
In fact, I did not take a master's degree.
I went right straight on through.
I see.
And had you finished your dissertation and everything before coming to Texas A&M?
No.
Again, circumstances dictates sometimes what we do.
The man that was in charge of animal genetics at Texas A&M accepted a job at the University of Arkansas, effective at mid-semester, February 1st.
And I was due to graduate, get my degree in June of 1930.
This had been 1936.
And so I applied and received an appointment to the position here.
So I came in February of 1936 and taught.
I taught five courses.
And I really hadn't any experience in teaching.
That was quite an experience to me to try to develop the course outlines and teach five new courses.
for the second semester of 1936.
And then I went back to Illinois in the summer, in June of 36, and finished my degree at the end of summer.
So at that point, coming as a brand new instructor with five different courses, I imagine you were lucky to keep a day ahead of the students.
I doubt if I did.
I doubt if I did.
I think I'd be bragging if I said I did.
Okay, and what information I had been able to pick up, you taught genetics.
Yes, yes, genetics, and I also had two courses in human heredity with the principles of genetics.
I taught one course in principles of genetics.
I taught one course in animal genetics.
And I taught two courses in human heredity.
One to non-people who had not had genetics.
They were engineers and architecture majors and so on.
And then another one was in human heredity to those who had had genetics.
Now, was this in the animal husbandry department?
No.
No, there was a separate department of genetics in those days, yes.
At what point was that discontinued, do you remember?
It was discontinued about 19I think about 1947 or 48.
I think there was still a genetics department.
When I came back from Hawaii, I was gone from A&M for about almost two years, and I came back in the poetry department here in 1947.
During the 36 to 45 that you were in genetics,
Were you head of the genetics department?
No, no, no, no.
You were on the faculty of that department.
No, I was the professor of animal genetics.
Within the genetics department.
Department, right, right.
Okay.
Then, I believe in 45, you went to Hawaii.
Yes, I went to Hawaii as head of the poaching department.
Did you choose to go there because it was a step up?
No, it was a step up, distinctly so, but I don't believe that was the major motivating factor.
The major motivating factor was that I had never been happy.
A&M was separate.
Research was in one area and teaching was in another.
And I had been in the teaching area solely.
And I wanted to do both teaching and research.
For graduate students, you've got to have both, you see.
And I wanted to emphasize the upper levels as much as I could.
And so for that reason, I'd never been happy.
And I had agitated and talked openly.
that they ought to be combined so that we could grow graduate student-wise at A&M, but it had never come to be.
And so when I was offered the job in Hawaii in 1945, I accepted it and resigned, turned in my resignation from Texas A&M University.
The dean called me in when the resignation passed the dean's desk.
He called me into his office and told me that there'd already been enough talk.
He asked me why I was resigning.
And I told him that the major reason was I could do both teaching and research.
They were all combined in a way.
And there would be no problem.
And in fact, all three of them were together, teaching and research.
And so he said, well, there's been enough talk.
that when the war is over, there's an extremely strong probability that the teaching and research will be combined, and agriculture will be combined here at Texas A&M University.
And would you take a leave of absence rather than resigning under that condition?
And so I wrote the dean and director at Hawaii and asked him if I could do this.
And he said, yes, indeed, it would be all right for me to do it.
And so then I changed.
They destroyed my resignation, and I turned in a leave request for a year's leave without pay to take the position.
And then I had to turn in a second year leave at the end of the first year that I was gone.
And so that was a motivating factor, I think, to do that.
As of 1945, though, you did have a considerable amount of graduate work in agriculture.
Yes, yes.
Oh, yes.
But most of the departments stopped.
Not all of them, but most of them stopped at the master's degree because, you see, the research was done in the experiment stations.
And so a graduate student, most of the teaching departments could possibly afford enough facility for a master's research program, but not for a dissertation program.
So if the student was going to the PhD, they almost had to be adopted by a full-time research worker in the experiment station.
There were no joint appointments then as now, I take it.
I don't know of any if there were.
There may have been a few, but there were very few, if any.
They were one or the other.
So you say a PhD almost had to be adopted by the experiment station.
So then, at that point, if someone went on for a PhD, he would have an academic advisor
in the department, I would take it, and research advisor in the experiment station.
They just weren't many went on that way.
It would have to have been a... That's the way it would have had to have been, yes, indeed.
Now, it's...
There's one further word.
I taught in the genetics department from 1936 to 45.
I taught genetics for nine months.
And then if I had graduate students, I continued the advising of the graduate students.
But for the summer months, I went to the experiment station and did research for three months.
Was that a fairly common practice for the faculty in agriculture?
Not very common.
Not very common.
I had to write a project.
for the experiment station, and they had to construct a building for the research to be done.
And so I think I got a little bit of favor to be able to do it.
Were you then doing poultry research in those summers?
No.
My research was mostly with rats.
Mr. Hale, Fred Hale,
had been doing some work on low vitamin A and its relation to eyelessness in swine.
And I had a strain.
I was carrying on a colony of rats in my genetics laboratory here in the instructional area.
And I had an eyeless strain of rats.
And I was anxious to know
whether the genotype that caused the eyelessness in these rats was influenced by nutrition.
And so you see that brought a commonness of interest there, and so it became relatively easy.
to get approved from the experiment station for a summer appointment and to carry my work over.
But to continue and discontinue was, of course, not like being continuous for 12 months.
Yeah.
So your research, you could really concentrate on your research for three months.
Yes.
Obviously, you'd have to carry it on for the other nine months, sort of.
as time was available, I think.
Right.
But when you went to Hawaii, you had both research and, well, you had actually research, teaching, and extension all combined.
Yes, right.
And so they were all in one department, and I taught one course in poetry science, and the rest of my time was spent on research.

Then, after two years, or about two years in Hawaii, you came back to Texas A&M as head of the... As head... Now, I was offered the job to come back at Texas A&M University as the man who had been head of the teaching department had retired.
And I was offered to come back as head of the teaching department, but I would not accept
the position unless I came back on a joint appointment between research and teaching.
And I was offered this joint appointment and I came back as head of the teaching department in September, 1st of September.
In November, the research, extension, and teaching were all combined.
And at that time, I really asked that somebody else take the headship.
But I was asked to do it and almost was urged to do it, and so I did assume the headship of all three areas as of November.
I guess it probably came effective December 1.
I'm not sure of the exact timing.
So at that point, people who had been in poultry science research in the Experiment Station came under your direction.
Right, right.
And then the poultry specialists in the extension service also came under you.
Yes.
So they could do some teaching in addition to what other work they were doing.
Yes.
And people who had been teaching exclusively...
were freed some teaching load to do some amount of research.
Right.
Actually, the department at that time, the extension has not changed very much.
There were four specialists.
There are four specialists here, local specialists, resident specialists,
and one field spaceless at the present time.
So the extension area has not changed.
As a matter of fact, there's reason for that because there was tremendous numbers of flocks and the extension was needed.
Perhaps the spaceless were needed in those days as much as today where there's much more poultry in the state.
But they're in large units, much fewer people carrying on the poke industry of the state, although it's many times the size it was then.
And so there has been little or no change there.
But the staff, there had to be a staff built for teaching and research.
And so it increased from a total of 2,000.
it increased a total of five to a total of thirteen in about a three-year period.
What is the poultry science department now teaching and research?
There's one less position than there was two years ago.
There was one position that was dropped.
That's all I know as far as I know.
So did it remain at 13 or from, say you said it rose from 5 to 13 within three years.
This would be, say, like 46 to 49.
Right.
Did it remain at the level of 13 quite steadily throughout?
Yes, yes.
There was no positions dropped.
or none added.
Yes, I take it back.
There was one position.
I better revise that because I was counting today.
There was twelve.
It rose to twelve.
There was one added in nineteen and forty, let's see, nineteen, is that it?
Yeah, about 1971, I think.
There was a new environmental control position added.
So it did increase by one position.
What about the course offerings within the Department of Poultry Husbandry, now Poultry Science?
Was that expanded considerably between, say, 46 and 72?
Yes, it was expanded in two ways.
The courses in poultry genetics and the course in poultry nutrition and the course in poultry management were all offered by the same man, or taught by the same man.
in 1945, really.
And now, of course, each one of those is offered by one or two independent people.
And there's been other courses added, and these courses that were added have been added only to be taught by individuals who were trained in that specialized area.
So there's been a change in terms of numbers of courses, and there's been a change
in the background of training of the man in charge of the course himself.
